Overall Score: 74 / 100
ãƒ»80â€“100 = Strong uptrend
ãƒ»60â€“79 = Mild uptrend
ãƒ»40â€“59 = Neutral / no clear direction
ãƒ»20â€“39 = Mild downtrend
ãƒ»0â€“19 = Strong downtrend
Direction: â€œMild uptrend.â€
Rate cuts at the upcoming FOMC are now seen as almost certain, futures leverage has been largely flushed, and the medium-term â€œfoundationâ€ for both BTC and ETH is strengthening. At the same time, short-term flash volatility risk around the event remains high.
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Market Summary
ãƒ»BTC has pulled back toward the CME gap while still sitting in a range with thick liquidity both above and below. Once it breaks either side, the move is likely to be large.
ãƒ»Kalshi markets now place the probability of a December Fed rate cut at 94%. The cut itself is mostly priced in; the key is to separate â€œthe violent moves right after the announcementâ€ from â€œthe trend over the following weeks.â€
ãƒ»Recent ETF flows show: modest net inflows into BTC, clear net outflows from ETH, and strong inflows into SOL. Capital is tilting toward â€œBTC for safety + SOL for high beta,â€ while ETH temporarily sits in a cleanup phase.
ãƒ»Open Interest continues a classic â€œrinse and repeatâ€: spikes higher, then gets wiped out. In this derivatives-driven market, price swings are noisy and do not always reflect underlying supplyâ€“demand.
ãƒ»Binance user numbers have finally passed 300 million, as CZ confirmed on X. Even in a bearish environment, trading infrastructure and the user base keep expandingâ€”crypto is still in the â€œadoption phase,â€ not the endgame.
ãƒ»In the Middle East, Tether USDâ‚® has been approved in Abu Dhabiâ€™s ADGM, and Dubai Customs has partnered with Binance to introduce crypto payments for trade and logistics. The region is strengthening its role as a real-world demand driver for stablecoins and crypto settlement.
ãƒ»Argentina will allow banks to offer crypto services from 2026. High-inflation countries are increasingly connecting banking and crypto at the national level.
ãƒ»BlackRock has filed for a staking-enabled ETH ETF. If institutional money flows in through a â€œyield-bearing ETH ETFâ€ wrapper, the structural impact on ETH demand could be significant.
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
On-chain & Technical Trends
ãƒ»BTC balances on exchanges continue to decline as coins move to long-term wallets. The main source of selling pressure is shrinking, a medium-term positive from a supply perspective.
ãƒ»In futures, Open Interest has dropped to near year-to-date lows and leverage has rapidly normalized. Speculative froth has been burned off, leaving a â€œlight order bookâ€ that can move sharply on new positive catalysts.
ãƒ»BTC taker buy volume has surged over the past two weeks. Dips are being aggressively bought, whales may be absorbing sell pressure, and short covering is adding fuelâ€”together supporting short-term upside momentum.
ãƒ»BTC/Gold 2-week RSI has fallen to the same depressed levels seen in 2014 and 2022. In both prior cases, these levels coincided with cycle bottoms, so the market is starting to price in a similar â€œrelative bottomâ€ scenario again.
ãƒ»Bitfinex whales have kept their BTC longs largely unchanged, with only tiny short exposure. This implies they are not particularly interested in betting on downside, while still waiting for the right moment to realize profits on the long side.
ãƒ»For ETH, around $2,800 there is a roughly $2.5B â€œfortress supportâ€ zone built by institutions and whales. Long-term holder realized price is almost identical to this level, making $2,800 an economically meaningful line that deep, sustained selling would have to overcome.
ãƒ»ETH ETFs saw a historic capitulation in November, with about $1.4B in net outflows. That flush looks like the final chapter of a leveraged, ETF-driven bubble. A reversal in flows from here would be a strong signal of a new medium-term trend.
ãƒ»ETH transaction counts and active addresses have started to rise clearly for the first time since entering the corrective phase. Meanwhile, daily fee revenue (90-day SMA) has dropped to the lowest level since 2017, showing both â€œweak current demandâ€ and â€œmassive room for mean reversion,â€ especially as post-Fusaka on-chain activity remains strong.
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Sentiment
ãƒ»Overall, sentiment is still closer to â€œFear,â€ but more people are talking about classic BTC bottoming patterns after capitulation and the possibility of a â€œSanta Rally.â€ The market is slowly shifting from extreme fear toward â€œcautious optimism.â€
ãƒ»According to Crypto Rover, institutional BTC buying has fallen to one of the lowest levels of this cycle. Historically, such â€œdemand troughsâ€ have often been followed by major reversals, so participants are watching closely for a turn in flows.
ãƒ»Darkfostâ€™s data shows that retail BTC inflows to Binance have fallen over 60% since the FTX collapse, with ETF channels now absorbing more retail demand. On-chain, â€œretail presenceâ€ is fading, typical of a quiet consolidation phase.
ãƒ»Bloombergâ€™s quant research suggests that the 2025 BTC decline was driven more by crypto-specific factorsâ€”particularly unusual selling from long-term holdersâ€”than by macro weakness. This strengthens the view that macro conditions remain structurally supportive for BTC.
ãƒ»Analysts like Ash Crypto and Glassnode highlight that BTC looks oversold relative to gold, while ETH fees are at multi-year lows. Both point to large upside potential once demand returns. Bernstein even argues that the traditional four-year BTC cycle is over and that BTC is ultimately headed toward $1M in a new structural regime.
ãƒ»On the other hand, US hiring plans and manufacturing employment have deteriorated to near-crisis levels, and ISM manufacturing employment remains deep in contraction. The creeping weakness in the real economy is a growing risk-off factor.
ãƒ»Mister Crypto notes that BTC now sits at an oversold zone where a stronger rebound could easily begin, and a seasonal â€œSanta Rallyâ€ would not be surprising. Among short-term traders, the bias is shifting from â€œshorting the dipâ€ to â€œwaiting to buy the reversal.â€
ãƒ»Overall, many participants are tired of the constant leverage flushes and are converging on a cautious consensus: instead of â€œtrying to predict every move,â€ keep positions light and wait patiently for asymmetric opportunities.
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
US Legacy Markets
ãƒ»This week is a â€œsuper weekâ€ with the FOMC rate decision, Powellâ€™s press conference, and key labor data. Standard Chartered and Citi expect a 25bp cut this week plus additional cuts into 2026, but markets are already assuming â€œno aggressive easing cycle,â€ just a gradual path.
ãƒ»The Fed has already ended QT, and discussions are turning toward â€œReserve Management Purchasesâ€â€”a more subtle form of liquidity provision that would function as a light version of QE. A turn in dollar liquidity would be a medium-term tailwind for crypto.
ãƒ»US gasoline prices have fallen to $2.95 per gallon, a four-year low. This supports consumer sentiment and helps push inflation lower, expanding the Fedâ€™s room for rate cuts.
ãƒ»At the same time, corporate hiring plans are the weakest since 2010, manufacturing jobs are shrinking more frequently, and the ISM manufacturing employment index is deeply contractionary. If this continues, recession fears will grow stronger.
ãƒ»The tug-of-war between AI and geopolitics continues, with the US expected to allow Nvidiaâ€™s H200 exports to Chinaâ€”a major policy shift that will impact supply chains and tech valuations. PMI, a key business cycle indicator, has shown surprisingly high correlation with â€œaltseasonâ€ indices, highlighting the linkage between macro cycles and crypto.
ãƒ»CEOs from Citi, BofA, and Wells Fargo are scheduled to brief US senators on the â€œcrypto market structureâ€ bill. This marks a new phase where top-tier TradFi leadership is directly involved in designing crypto regulation.
ãƒ»Alongside US debates, regulators worldwide are accelerating work on stablecoin and on-chain frameworks. The EUâ€™s MiCA example is fueling expectations that â€œclear rules = growth driver,â€ not necessarily a brake on the market.
ãƒ»BTC is currently trading near the average cost basis of spot ETF holders. Whether this level holds will be a key test of institutional confidence in the asset over the short term.
â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Overall Assessment
The market has moved into a state where â€œthe foundation is quite healthy, but short-term flash volatility can erupt at any time.â€ OI has dropped, leverage has been cleaned out, and Derivatives risk is much lower. At the same time, ETHâ€™s $2,800 fortress support, classic BTC post-capitulation patterns, and the sense that ETF and institutional deleveraging is largely complete all point to a medium-term strengthening of fundamentals and supplyâ€“demand.
Todayâ€™s XWIN TREND INDEX is 74 / 100, with a directional bias of â€œMild uptrend.â€
Looking one month ahead, this FOMC has the potential to be a turning point for the trio of â€œrates, dollar, and liquidity.â€ As seen in the last two rate-cut episodes, the pattern of â€œinitial spike after the announcement, followed by a different trend in the weeks afterâ€ could repeat. That is why, once again, â€œpreparingâ€ is more important than â€œpredicting.â€ The priority now is to keep leverage minimal, gradually accumulate spot BTC, ETH, and select L1s (such as SOL), and continuously track ETF flows, OI, and key on-chain signals (especially ETH activity and BTC whale behavior). A stance of â€œconstructively bullish, but with position sizing and event-volatility risk management as the top priorityâ€ is appropriate for this phase.
